## False Memory

![](images/Experiment_kids.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="90"}

<p style="font-size: 30px;"> False memory refers to the distorted recollection of an event that happened in the past, or the recollection of an event that never happened. </p>


::: {layout-ncol="2"}

::: col

:::{.fragment}
<p style="font-size: 25px; padding-top: 25px;">**Some causes of False Memory:**</p>
:::

<ul style ="font-size:21px; padding-top: 15px;">

:::{.fragment}
<li> **Interference:** A new event interferes with the memory of a previous event. For example, novel negative information about a person may cause negative false memories abuot our previous interactions with that person (*retroactive interference*). </li> 
:::

:::{.fragment}

<li> **Leading Questions:** Question that either contain or attempt to elicit incorrect information about a past events have been known to cause false memories. For example, "Did you see **that** person?" (potentially leading) VS "Did you see **any** person?" (not leading). </li>

:::

:::{.fragment}

<li> **Similarity between events/stimuli:** Probably one of the most common false memory causes is the similarity between stimuli/events. When asked about events that did not happen, which have features of events that did happen, people often report false memories. </li> 

:::

</ul>

:::


:::col

</br>

<center>

![](images/False_memory.png)

</center>

:::

## The DRM task

![](images/Experiment_kids.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="90"}


<p style="font-size: 30px;"> The **Deese‚ÄìRoediger‚ÄìMcDermott (DRM; [Rodiger & McDermott, 1995](https://psych.hanover.edu/classes/cognition/Papers/RoedigerMcDermott%201996%20DRM%20False.pdf)) paradigm ** is one of the most popular experimental procedures to generate false memories.</p>

::: {layout-ncol="2"}

:::col

<center>
::: {.fragment fragment-index="1"}
<p style="font-size: 30px;"> **Encoding Phase** </p>


![](images/Memorization.png){width="120" height="110"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index="2"}
<p style="font-size: 24px;"> Participants are told to learn a set of *semantically related* words. For example: </p>
:::


::: {.fragment fragment-index="3"}
<p style="font-size: 24px;"> **Mountain, cliff, peak, chasm, etc...**</p>
:::

</br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index="4"}
<p style="font-size: 24px;"> usually the list will have 8 or more words. </p>
:::




</center>


:::


:::col

<center>

::: {.fragment fragment-index="1"}

<p style="font-size: 30px;"> **Recognition Phase** </p>

![](images/Detective.png){width="120" height="110"}

:::


::: {.fragment fragment-index="5"}
<p style="font-size: 24px;"> Participants are then present another list of words and asked to identify words that were presented in encoding phase: </p>
:::


::: {.fragment fragment-index="6"}
<p style="font-size: 24px;"> **door**, [**peak**]{style="color: green;"}, **hammer**, [**hill**]{style="color: red;"}, [**cliff**]{style="color: green;"}, [**summit**]{style="color: red;"}, **etc...** </p>
:::



::: {.fragment fragment-index="7"}
<p style="font-size: 24px;"> Where participants will be more likely to incorrectly identify [**semantically related**]{style="color: red;"} words such as *hill* than **semantically unrelated** words such as *door*. </p>
:::



</center>


:::


:::


<center>

::: {.fragment fragment-index="8"}
<p style="font-size: 24px;"> üí°The DRM task is actually what was used in the experiment that you just completedüí° </p>
:::

</center>


## The Mandela Effect

![](images/Experiment_kids.png){.absolute top=-50 right=-50 width="120" height="90"}

<p style="font-size: 28px;"> The **Mandela effect** is a phenomenon whereby multiple people consistently exhibit false memories about a famous person or a popular culture icon.
